content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="/xsl/oairepository/oai2.xsl.v1.0" ?> <OAI-PMH xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/OAI-PMH.xsd"> <responseDate>2015-03-12T22:15:19Z</responseDate><request verb="ListRecords" set="user-cool-stars" metadataPrefix="oai_dc">http://zenodo.org/oai2d</request><ListRecords> <record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10572</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:25Z</datestamp><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-nymg</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-young-bds</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Gagn\ufffd\ufffd, Jonathan</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Lafreni\ufffd\ufffdre, David</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Doyon, Ren\ufffd\ufffd</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Malo, Lison</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Artigau, \ufffd\ufffdtienne</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Faherty, Jacqueline</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Cruz, Kelle</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Delorme, Philippe</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Results from the BANYAN All-Sky Syrvey</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10572</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.6084/m9.figshare.1050519</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>We performed an all-sky cross-match of the 2MASS and WISE catalogs to search for new very late-type (&gt; M5) candidate members to young, moving groups using the BANYAN statistical tool to create the BASS catalog. We present follow-up results of this catalog, unveiling many new young BDs and new directly imaged exoplanets. These late-type and young objects will be very compelling targets for the search of exoplanets by direct imaging, due to their youth and proximity. Their moving group membership also provides useful constraints on their age.</p></dc:description>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10573</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:25Z</datestamp><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>openaire</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Patel, Rahul</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Metchev, Stanimir</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Heinze, Aren</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Finding Warm Debris Disks with WISE Around Bright Stars</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10573</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10573</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>We present a sensitive search for&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 (12 &mu;m) and&nbsp;<em>W</em>4 (22 &mu;m) excesses from warm optically thin dust around&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;main sequence stars within 75 pc from the Sun. We use contemporaneously measured photometry from&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>, remove sources of contamination, and derive and apply corrections to saturated fluxes to attain optimal sensitivity to &gt;10 &mu;m excesses. We use data from the&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;All-Sky Survey Catalog rather than the AllWISE release because we find that its saturated photometry is better behaved, allowing us to detect small excesses even around saturated stars in&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>. Our new discoveries increase by 45% the number of stars with warm dusty excesses and expand the number of known debris disks (with excess at any wavelength) within 75 pc by 29%. We identify 220&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;debris disk host stars, 108 of which are new detections at any wavelength. We present the first measurement of a 12&nbsp;&mu;m and/or 22&nbsp;&mu;m excess for 10 stars with previously known cold (50-100 K) disks. We also find five new stars with small but significant&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 excesses, adding to the small population of known exozodi, and we detect evidence for a&nbsp;<em>W</em>2 excess around HIP&nbsp;96562 (F2V), indicative of tenuous hot (780 K) dust. As a result of our&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;study, the number of debris disks with known 10-30&nbsp;&mu;m excesses within 75 pc (379) has now surpassed the number of disks with known &gt;30 &mu;m excesses (289, with 171 in common), even if the latter have been found to have a higher occurrence rate in unbiased samples.</p></dc:description>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10584</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:38Z</datestamp><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Gullikson, Kevin</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Kraus, Adam</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Dodson-Robinson, Sarah</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Hot Stars with Cool Companions</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10584</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10584</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>We present intermediate results of a spectroscopic survey for late K-M companions orbiting nearby A and B type stars. Such companions may have formed in the massive disk of the young primary star, and so may be scaled-up versions of brown dwarfs formed in the disks of less massive stars. In addition, the multiplicity of these bright and young A and B type stars is important to generate samples for adaptive optics planet searches. The method we use to search for companions has a uniform detection threshold for any companion within about 2-3&quot;, and so is complementary to ongoing imaging surveys. We find companion stars with a variety of masses, giving early indication that these companions <em>do not</em> form through gravitational disk instability, which would preferentially produce low-mass stars.</p></dc:description>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10592</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:38Z</datestamp><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:source>Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series: 212 (2014) no. 1, </dc:source>   <dc:creator>Patel, Rahul</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Metchev, Stanimir</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Heinze, Aren</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Finding Warm Debris Disks with WISE Around Bright Stars</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10592</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10592</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>We present a sensitive search for&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 (12 &mu;m) and&nbsp;<em>W</em>4 (22 &mu;m) excesses from warm optically thin dust around&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;main sequence stars within 75 pc from the Sun. We use contemporaneously measured photometry from&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>, remove sources of contamination, and derive and apply corrections to saturated fluxes to attain optimal sensitivity to &gt;10 &mu;m excesses. We use data from the&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;All-Sky Survey Catalog rather than the AllWISE release because we find that its saturated photometry is better behaved, allowing us to detect small excesses even around saturated stars in&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>. Our new discoveries increase by 45% the number of stars with warm dusty excesses and expand the number of known debris disks (with excess at any wavelength) within 75 pc by 29%. We identify 220&nbsp;<em>Hipparcos</em>&nbsp;debris disk host stars, 108 of which are new detections at any wavelength. We present the first measurement of a 12&nbsp;&mu;m and/or 22&nbsp;&mu;m excess for 10 stars with previously known cold (50-100 K) disks. We also find five new stars with small but significant&nbsp;<em>W</em>3 excesses, adding to the small population of known exozodi, and we detect evidence for a&nbsp;<em>W</em>2 excess around HIP&nbsp;96562 (F2V), indicative of tenuous hot (780 K) dust. As a result of our&nbsp;<em>WISE</em>&nbsp;study, the number of debris disks with known 10-30&nbsp;&mu;m excesses within 75 pc (379) has now surpassed the number of disks with known &gt;30 &mu;m excesses (289, with 171 in common), even if the latter have been found to have a higher occurrence rate in unbiased samples.</p></dc:description>   <dc:publisher/>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10599</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:39Z</datestamp><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-nymg</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Rodriguez, David</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Zuckerman, Ben</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Kastner, Joel</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Vican, Laura</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Principe, David</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Faherty, Jacqueline</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Murphy, Simon</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Bessell, Mike</dc:creator>   <dc:title>New Results from the GALEX Nearby Young-Star Survey</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-18</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10599</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10599</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>The last few decades have seen the discovery of many 10-100 Myr-old stars in moving groups within 100 parsecs of Earth. The present membership of these groups, however, is still incomplete at the lowest masses.</p>  <p>We have initiated a program, the GALEX Nearby Young-Star Survey, or GALNYSS, to search for these missing M-stars. GALNYSS has combined ultraviolet data from GALEX with near-IR surveys (WISE and 2MASS), as well as kinematic information, in order to identify over 2000 candidate young low-mass stars near Earth. Spectroscopic follow-up is ongoing, and results thus far confirm the youthful nature of many stars among the GALNYSS sample. This suggests that our technique is capable of revealing the populations of low-mass stars that are presently missing from the nearby young moving groups. We present an overview of our survey to date, including the characteristics of the GALNYSS sample and highlights from GALNYSS&#39;s latest contributions to our knowledge of the number and membership of nearby, young stellar associations.&nbsp;</p>  <p>This work is supported by NASA Astrophysics Data Analysis Program award NNX12AH37G to RIT and UCLA and Chilean FONDECYT grant 3130520 to Universidad de Chile.</p></dc:description>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10602</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:38:39Z</datestamp><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Opitz, Daniela</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Tinney, Chris</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Searching for binary Y dwarfs with the Gemini Multi-Conjugate Adaptive Optics System (GeMS)</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-20</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10602</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10602</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>The NASA Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) has delivered an exceptional harvest of new ultra-cool Y-type brown dwarfs. We present results from a diffraction-limited study of the binary status of a sample of Y dwarfs observed with the Gemini GeMS Multi-Conjugate Adaptive Optics system. We report no evidence of equal mass/luminosity binaries at separations larger than ~ 0.5 -2.0 AU for six Y dwarfs.</p></dc:description>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:10649</identifier><datestamp>2014-07-04T11:26:51Z</datestamp><setSpec>openaire</setSpec><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Feiden, Gregory</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Chaboyer, Brian</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Jones, Jaquille</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Updating the Dartmouth stellar evolution model grid: Pre-main-sequence models & magnetic fields</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-06-25</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/10649</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.10649</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>Poster from The 18th Workshop on Cool Stars, Stellar Systems, and the Sun on updating the Dartmouth stellar evolution model grid. Additions include models of pre-main-sequence stars, magnetic fields, deuterium burning, and a revised treatment of surface boundary conditions.</p></dc:description>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record><record><header><identifier>oai:zenodo.org:11056</identifier><datestamp>2014-08-08T22:39:11Z</datestamp><setSpec>user-cool-stars</setSpec><setSpec>user-zenodo</setSpec><setSpec>openaire</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">   <dc:creator>Newton, Elisabeth R.</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Charbonneau, David</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Irwin, Jonathan</dc:creator>   <dc:creator>Mann, Andrew W.</dc:creator>   <dc:title>Temperatures and radii of low mass dwarfs  inferred from NIR spectra</dc:title>   <dc:date>2014-07-27</dc:date>   <dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject>   <dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/11056</dc:identifier>   <dc:identifier>           doi:10.5281/zenodo.11056</dc:identifier>   <dc:description><p>We present a new empirical calibration for the radii, temperatures, and luminosities of cool dwarf stars. Our calibration, based on stars with bolometric fluxes and interferometric radii, uses the EWs of atomic features in moderate resolution H-band spectra. We apply our calibration to two samples of stars: the nearby M dwarfs targeted by MEarth and the cool Kepler Objects of Interest.</p></dc:description>   <dc:rights>         info:eu-repo/semantics/openAccess       </dc:rights>   <dc:type>       info:eu-repo/semantics/article     </dc:type> </oai_dc:dc> </metadata></record></ListRecords> </OAI-PMH>
